revisions.rev:
{{Infobox individual golf tournament | name = 2010 Masters Tournament | image = | dates = April 8â11, 2010 | location = [[Augusta, Georgia]] | course = [[Augusta National Golf Club]] | tour = [[PGA Tour]]
[[PGA European Tour]]
[[Japan Golf Tour]] | par = 72 | yardage = 7,435 | field = 96 players (48 after cut) | cut = +3 | purse = $7,500,000 | winners_share = $1,350,000 | champion = [[Phil Mickelson]] | score = 272 (-16) }} The '''2010 Masters Tournament''', played April 8â11 at [[Augusta National Golf Club]], was the 74th [[Masters Tournament]]. This was the first major championship of the [[2010 in golf|2010]] season. [[Phil Mickelson]] won his third Masters title by three shots over runner-up [[Lee Westwood]].{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/golf/mastersaugusta/7579868/Masters-2010-Phil-Mickelson-holds-off-Lee-Westwood-to-claim-third-green-jacket.html|title=Masters 2010: Phil Mickelson holds off Lee Westwood to claim third green jacket|date=2010-04-11|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=Telegraph Media Group|first=Mark|last=Reason|location=[[Augusta, Georgia|Augusta]]|accessdate=2010-04-12}} ==Field== The Masters has the smallest field of the major championships. Officially the Masters remains an invitation event, but there is now a qualification process. In theory, the club could simply decline to invite a qualified player. This is the list of the 96 players who played in the 2010 Masters Tournament.[http://www.masters.com/en_US/players/invitees_2010.html 2010 Masters Tournament Invitees] Each player is classified according to the first category by which he qualified, but other categories are shown in parentheses. '''1. Past [[Masters Tournament|Masters]] Champions'''
[[Ãngel Cabrera]] (2,11,15,17,18,19), [[Fred Couples]], [[Ben Crenshaw]], [[Trevor Immelman]], [[Zach Johnson]] (15,16,17,18,19), [[Bernhard Langer]], [[Sandy Lyle]], [[Phil Mickelson]] (4,5,11,12,15,16,17,18,19), [[Larry Mize]], [[Mark O'Meara]], [[Vijay Singh]] (18,19), [[Craig Stadler]], [[Tom Watson (golfer)|Tom Watson]] (13), [[Mike Weir]] (15,17,18,19), [[Tiger Woods]] (2,3,4,11,12,14,15,16,17,18,19), [[Ian Woosnam]] (Past champions who did not play: [[Tommy Aaron]], [[Seve Ballesteros]], [[Jack Burke, Jr.]], [[Billy Casper]], [[Charles Coody]], [[Nick Faldo]], [[Doug Ford (golfer)|Doug Ford]], [[Raymond Floyd]],[http://www.majorschampionships.com/masters/2010/news/floyf_retires.cfm Four-time major winner Floyd calls it a career] [[Bob Goalby]], [[Jack Nicklaus]], [[JosÃ© MarÃ­a OlazÃ¡bal]],[http://www.sportinglife.com/golf/news/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=golf/10/03/17/GOLF_Olazabal.html Olazabal To Miss Masters] [[Arnold Palmer]], [[Gary Player]], and [[Fuzzy Zoeller]]). Palmer and Nicklaus were named "honorary starters" and teed off on the first day at the first hole, but did not complete the round. '''2. Last five [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] Champions'''

|| 1988 || 69 || 86 || 155 || +11 |- | align=left|[[Craig Stadler]] || align=left|{{USA}} || 1982 || 79 || 78 || 157 || +13 |- | align=left|[[Ian Woosnam]] || align=left|{{WAL}} || 1991 || 81 || 83 || 164 || +20 |} ==Par 3 Contest== [[Louis Oosthuizen]] won the contest with a 6 under par 21. There were 2 [[hole in one|holes in one]] during the contest, both on the 9th hole, achieved by [[Graeme McDowell]] and [[Jim Furyk]].{{cite news |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/golf/stories/040810dnspomastersdate.3ec1ea8.html |title=Oosthuizen wins Par-3 Contest at Masters |newspaper=[[The Dallas Morning News]] |first=Bill |last=Nichols |date=April 7, 2010 |accessdate=2010-07-23}} McDowell went on to win the [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]], Oosthuizen went on to win [[The Open Championship]], and Furyk went on to win the 2010 [[FedEx Cup]]. ==First round== The day started very sunny, but clouds began accumulating later in the morning and thunderstorms were expected in the afternoon; however, the weather remained fair. The much anticipated return of [[Tiger Woods]] came on Thursday, who shot a 4-under 68. This was a good opening for Woods, who had never before shot a first round in the 60s at the Masters.{{cite news|url=http://www.theprovince.com/sports/Golf+still+easy+Woods/2781736/story.html|title=Golf still easy for Woods|last=Willes|first=Ed|date=April 9, 2010|work=[[The Province]]|accessdate=April 9, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} But the story of the day was the two [[Champions Tour]] players, 60 year-old [[Tom Watson (golfer)|Tom Watson]] and 50 year-old [[Fred Couples]], who shot 67 and 66 respectively. Major champions [[Phil Mickelson]] and [[Yang Yong-eun]] were one stroke back of leader Couples along with [[Lee Westwood]], [[Choi Kyung-Ju|K. J. Choi]], and Watson.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/golf/8610574.stm|title=Tiger Woods in hunt as Fred Couples takes Masters lead|date=2010-04-09|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|first=Rob|last=Hodgetts|location=[[Augusta, Georgia|Augusta]]|accessdate=2010-04-12}} {| class="wikitable" !#!!Player!!Country!!Score!!To par |- |rowspan="1" align=center|1||[[Fred Couples]]||{{USA}}||rowspan="1" align=center|66||rowspan="1" align=center|-6 |- |rowspan="5" align=center|T2||[[Choi Kyung-Ju|K. J. Choi]]||{{KOR}}||rowspan="5" align=center|67||rowspan="5" align=center|-5 |- |[[Phil Mickelson]]||{{USA}} |- |[[Tom Watson (golfer)|Tom Watson]]||{{USA}} |- |[[Lee Westwood]]||{{ENG}} |- |[[Yang Yong-eun]]||{{KOR}} |- |rowspan="5" align=center|T7||[[Ricky Barnes]]||{{USA}}||rowspan="5" align=center|68||rowspan="5" align=center|-4 |- |[[Anthony Kim]]||{{USA}} |- |[[Ian Poulter]]||{{ENG}} |- |[[Nick Watney]]||{{USA}} |- |[[Tiger Woods]]||{{USA}} |} ==Second round== [[Phil Mickelson]] shot a 1-under 71 despite missing a 1-foot putt on Hole 5. [[Fred Couples]] and [[Tom Watson (golfer)|Tom Watson]] both fell back after solid opening rounds. Englishmen [[Lee Westwood]] and [[Ian Poulter]] shared the lead heading into the weekend.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/golf/8612534.stm|title=Lee Westwood and Ian Poulter share Masters halfway lead|date=2010-04-09|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|first=Rob|last=Hodgetts|location=[[Augusta, Georgia|Augusta]]|accessdate=2010-04-12}} {| class="wikitable" !#!!Player!!Country!!Score!!To par |- |rowspan="2" align=center|T1||[[Ian Poulter]]||{{ENG}}||68-68=136||rowspan="2" align=center|-8 |- |[[Lee Westwood]]||{{ENG}}||67-69=136 |- |rowspan="5" align=center|T3||[[Ricky Barnes]]||{{USA}}||68-70=138||rowspan="5" align=center|-6 |- |[[Choi Kyung-Ju|K. J. Choi]]||{{KOR}}||67-71=138 |- |[[Anthony Kim]]||{{USA}}||68-70=138 |- |[[Phil Mickelson]]||{{USA}}||67-71=138 |- |[[Tiger Woods]]||{{USA}}||68-70=138 |- |align=center|8||[[Yang Yong-eun]]||{{KOR}}||align=center|67-72=139||align=center|-5 |- |rowspan="3" align=center|T9||[[Fred Couples]]||{{USA}}||66-75=141||rowspan="3" align=center|-3 |- |[[SÃ¸ren Kjeldsen]]||{{DNK}}||70-71=141 |- |[[Tom Watson (golfer)|Tom Watson]]||{{USA}}||67-74=141 |} Amateurs: ''[[Matteo Manassero|Manassero]] (+3)'', Smith (+5), [[Brad Benjamin|Benjamin]] (+6), [[An Byeong-hun|An]] (+11), Han (+11), [[Ben Martin (golfer)|Martin]] (+11). ==Third round== [[Lee Westwood]] continued his solid play in the third round to stay in the lead. [[Phil Mickelson]] shot a 67, including a dramatic eagle-eagle-birdie on 13, 14 and 15, to move into second place, three strokes clear of the rest of the field.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/golf/8613390.stm|title=Lee Westwood holds off Phil Mickelson for Masters lead|date=2010-04-11|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|first=Rob|last=Hodgetts|location=[[Augusta, Georgia|Augusta]]|accessdate=2010-04-12}} {| class="wikitable" !#!!Player!!Country!!Score!!To par |- |align=center|1||[[Lee Westwood]]||{{ENG}}||67-69-68=204||align=center|-12 |- |align=center|2||[[Phil Mickelson]]||{{USA}}||67-71-67=205||align=center|-11 |- |rowspan="2" align=center|T3||[[Choi Kyung-Ju|K. J. Choi]]||{{KOR}}||67-71-70=208||rowspan="2" align=center|-8 |- |[[Tiger Woods]]||{{USA}}||68-70-70=208 |- |align=center|5||[[Fred Couples]]||{{USA}}||66-75-68=209||align=center|-7 |- |rowspan="3" align=center|T6||[[Ricky Barnes]]||{{USA}}||68-70-72=210||rowspan="3" align=center|-6 |- |[[Hunter Mahan]]||{{USA}}||71-71-68=210 |- |[[Ian Poulter]]||{{ENG}}||68-68-74=210 |- |rowspan="2" align=center|T9||[[Anthony Kim]]||{{USA}}||68-70-73=211||rowspan="2" align=center|-5 |- |[[Yang Yong-eun]]||{{KOR}}||67-72-72=211 |} ==Final round== [[Fred Couples]] mounted an early charge up the leaderboard with two birdies in his first three holes, but he quickly cooled off and ended up in sixth place. Overnight leader [[Lee Westwood]] started erratically, while [[Phil Mickelson]] parred his first seven holes. [[Choi Kyung-Ju|K. J. Choi]] was briefly tied for the lead at -12 with a birdie at 10 but he eventually fell back to a tie for fourth with playing partner [[Tiger Woods]] (they were paired together for all four rounds of the tournament). 24-year old [[Anthony Kim]] shot a blistering 65, including a -5 run over four holes; he finished third. But down the stretch, Mickelson pulled away from Westwood with a bogey-free round of 67 to win the tournament.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/golf/8614407.stm|title=Mickelson seals third Masters win|date=2010-04-11|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|first=Rob|last=Hodgetts|location=[[Augusta, Georgia|Augusta]]|accessdate=2010-04-12}} {| class="wikitable" !#!!Player!!Country!!Score!!To par |- |align=center|1||'''[[Phil Mickelson]]'''||{{USA}}||67-71-67-67=272||align=center|-16 |- |align=center|2||[[Lee Westwood]]||{{ENG}}||67-69-68-71=275||align=center|-13 |- |align=center|3||[[Anthony Kim]]||{{USA}}||68-70-73-65=276||align=center|-12 |- |rowspan="2" align=center|T4|| [[Choi Kyung-Ju|K.
